Award.AwardTitle: Exploring the WIMP Parameter Space Above and Below the Neutrino Floor
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities on dark matter of Professor Louis Strigari at Indiana University. Dark matter comprises about 80% of the total matter in the Universe. However, it has not yet been directly detected and its identify remains a mystery. A leading candidate for dark matter would be a new elementary particle of nature, and identifying this particle is one of the foremost goals of modern science. The research within this project provides a crucial input to experiments that are searching for dark matter particles over the course of the next decade.

As the various experimental searches for particle dark matter increase in size and improve in sensitivity, new challenges will arise in attempts to extract a possible signal. For direct dark matter searches, an important background in the future will be the "neutrino floor"; this is defined as the scale at which detectors are large enough to detect neutrinos produced from the Sun, atmosphere, and supernovae. Detectors are now fast approaching the scale at which these neutrinos will appear, so it is imperative to make a concerted effort towards understanding their spectra so that they may be properly identified. The funding under this award will be utilized to study theoretical and experimental methods to reduce the uncertainty on the neutrino backgrounds in dark matter detectors. The work will involve theoretical predictions, statistical data modeling, and analysis of many modern dark matter and neutrino experiments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most of the mass in the universe is in the form of dark matter. Dark matter binds galaxies together, and is responsible for seeding the underlying patterns that astronomers discern on the largest obervable scales in the universe. Though much is known about this large scale distribution of dark matter, its microscopic identity is unknown to physicists and astronomers. For example, basic questions about dark matter are: How massive is it? How does it interact with particles that are known in nature? How was dark matter created in the early universe?

The scientific evidence favors the hypothesis that dark matter is an elementary particle of nature, that experiments have to this point been unable to identify. There are many experments, and many different experimental methods, that are being attempted around the world to identify the nature of this particle. One particular method is so-called `direct dark matter detection.' In this method, experiments search for dark matter interactions with an atomic nucleus, and attempt to detect the energy deposited into the nucleus by a dark matter particle. These experiments have to be delicately designed in order to avoid backgrounds that may mimic a dark matter signal. 

The direct detection experiments are becoming so sensitive, that soon they will encounter a new type of background: neutrinos from the sun and from the atmosphere. Neutrinos are the most weakly-interacting particles known in nature so it is a testament to how good the experiments are that they will be sensitive to such feebly-interacting particles. 

In this project, theoretical calculations were performed to gauge how well future experiments will do in discriminating between neutrino and dark matter particle interactions. Key outcomes were obtained as follows. Theoretical calculations were performed to gauge the prospects that future experiments with sensitivity to the direction of the recoiling nucleus will do in discriminating between neutrinos and dark matter. In detectors with this sensitivity, neutrinos from the Sun could be subtracted from dark matter signals, the latter of which would come from all directions.  

Theoretical calculations were also performed to examine whether neutrinos have interactions with known particles that different than the standard interactions that are typically assumed. These so-called ‘non-standard’ interactions may be identified in future experiments that are motivated by measuring a dark matter signal. It was found that these types of experiments can have unique sensitivity to such non-standard interactions, highlighting how future detectors can serve the dual purpose of searching for dark matter and studying fundamental properties of neutrinos. 

It is also possible to study such non-standard neutrino interactions through terrestrial neutrino sources, including nuclear reactors and accelerators. The COHERENT experiment has recently performed a novel measurements of neutrino interactions on an atomic nucleus. This research also studied how these types of terrestrial experiments are able to search for non-standard neutrino interactions, and how they complement measurements made by future dark mater detectors.
